page.title: 09WILD FLOWERS OF THE N. TYNE
page.content: The range of flowers is wide, as the haabitat covers riverside, to moorland and woodland. By the river, waterweed, meadowsweet and marsh marigolds grow. Bluebells, dogs mercury, primroses,wood anemones and wood sorrel are seen{in the woods,}as well as lady's mantle and the strongly scented ramson.{In marshes}on open land, sundew and butterwort grow. On drier ground, violets, thyme and tormentil spread.{Along the roadside } verges we find dandelions, purple and yellow vetch, celandines, groundsel, coltsfoot and daises. The hedges hold cow parsley, lady's bedstraw,cross- wort, stitchwort, chickweed, ragged robin and bladder campion. The{pasture {land}has buttercups, red and white clover, pignut and patches of thistles The high ground has milkwort and stretches of heather.
